newsitem.title: USA: Florida home resales hold steady in 1997 Q1.
newsitem.headline: Florida home resales hold steady in 1997 Q1.

text.p: Florida sales of existing single-family homes totalled 26,455 in the first quarter of 1997, unchanged from the blazing pace set a year ago, the Florida Association of Realtors said Thursday.
The median resale price rose to $91,500 during the quarter, up two percent over the same period last year.

The sales volume matched the pace set in the 1996 first quarter, when falling interest rates spurred buyers to action. Rates fell from an average of 8.8 percent in early 1995 to 7.3 percent a year ago.

The average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage edged back up to 7.8 percent in the 1997 first quarter, but buyers relocating from out of state helped keep the pace steady, the association said.
Resales jumped by 10 percent over the first quarter of last year in the Tampa-St. Petersburg area.
"We're seeing quite a few executive-type buyers, as well, and that makes our median sales price go up," said Tampa realtor Marie Powell.

Other areas posting increases in home resales for the quarter were Punta Gorda, up 31 percent; Fort Myers-Cape Coral, up 18 percent; Pensacola, up 11 percent; Ocala, up nine percent; Naples and Bradenton-Sarasota, both up eight percent; Jacksonville, up six percent; Gainesville, up two percent; and Fort Pierce-Port St. Lucie, up one percent.

Areas posting declines fromt he first quarter of last year were Lakeland-Winter Haven, down 21 percent; Fort Lauderdale, down 20 percent; Tallahassee, down 14 percent; West Palm Beach, down 13 percent; Panama City, down eight percent; Orlando, down five percent; Miami, down four percent; and Daytona Beach and Melbourne-Titusville, both down two percent.
